body: Thank you @mboehm7. I will also remove the IBM flex scheduler configuration in a separate PR.

Note: I spoke with a user today who expressed confusion with regards to the config file warning. If need be, we might even want to drop the message log level to INFO if we receive additional such feedback.
Also, I agree about the `-config` vs `-config=` issue. The use of the equals sign for only this flag is confusing and inconsistent with the other flags.
LGTM

1) I'm favor of the cleanup regarding the -config flag (just for completeness, there is one more configuration -Dsystemml.logging=DEBUG w/ similar syntax, but this is due to the JVM -D option)
2) Regarding the warning: let's modify the message if needed but keep it in WARN for now - otherwise people don't think about it which can be disastrous if /tmp is mounted to some small disk (potentially leading to "no space left on device"). 
3) Further, before we can remove the merge logic, let's please discuss on the JIRA. The use case is the following: Assume SystemML and it's config file is put into some system directory on each node in a shared cluster. This means all users of that cluster share the common setup. However, individual users can overwrite any subset of configurations. With the change, a user would be forced to suddenly specify ALL configurations. I'm fine with this for release 1.0 but you need to give people some time to raise concerns.
Tests passed successfully [here](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/143/). I will merge.

Arvind, thanks for the changes (I really would like to have this feature as soon as possible) but this patch needs a major rework:

1) Algorithm correctness: There are various scenarios, where your algorithm would currently create incorrect results: (a) missing else branches, (b) missing function handling, and (c) incorrect hop consumer checks. For example in "isInLoop", you only investigate the if branch, you never jump into related functions, and you only investigate hop DAG root nodes (missing recursive DAG processing w/ memoization) - we want to check parents of transient read, not inputs to transient write. 
2) Optimizer performance: Please recompile each statement block just once if required, not for every candidate that might be in the same block.
3) Simplifications: I would also strongly suggest various simplifications to make the code easier to understand and debug. First, you don't need separate cases for parfor and for if you do equivalent things; parfor is subclass of for, so any for handling covers both. Second,  you could do almost everything in getUIPConsumerList, isInLoop and validateUIPConsumerList on OptNodes which allows for simple tree processing (because it only represents containment) - only for leaf nodes, you get the associated Hop and do the remaining checking. Third, is this UIPCandidateHop really required? Almost all the information is available at hops and optnodes.
4) Code cleanup: First, please wrap any log debug messages into LOG.isDebugEnabled, especially if you construct strings. Second, please use foreach instead of indexed access on collections  unless you need the index or remove elements from the lists. Third, please don't use "} else {" - it is unreadable.
5) Tests: First, you need to put the (1==1){} cut into the function; otherwise your function is inlined. Second, a couple of tests regarding the issues raised under 1) would be good. Third, please move your specific code out of AutomatedTestBase into your own tests. 
6) Statistics: The maintenance of update in-place counters is currently not thread-safe. Since the only place where this is used is parfor, you need to add this. Please either remove or use atomics/synchronized.
7) Explain: It would be good not to introduce unnecessary complexity. Since, update in-place markers are only set on DataOp, we should extend the output for DataOps of type tread, maybe only if it is marked for update in place.

@deroneriksson, @mboehm7 Great, thanks for the feedback.  I've written up more information regarding the decision to remove the merging logic on the associated [JIRA issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-495), and have invited further discussion there.
@nakul02 could you please do me a favor and squash these commits into a single commit to ease the review. Thanks.
Fixed and set another [Jenkins build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/87/).
LGTM; @deroneriksson could you, however, please change the title - initially I thought you're about to put generated files into our repo (what we don't want).
@mboehm7 Thank you for reviewing. I updated the title to hopefully avoid confusion.
@mboehm7 could you please take a look?
Preview at http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/contributing-to-systemml.html
LGTM

Thanks Deron for creating this. It will be of great help for new users. 

LGTM
@lresende Does all the license info in the standalone LICENSE need to be included in the project root-level LICENSE?

@nakul02 in general, the patch looks already good - just a couple of cleanups (some of these issues exist for a while - we should use the opportunity to resolve them):

1) Redundancy: There still seems to be some unnecessary redundancy. Examples include (a) the handling of control structures, (b) function parameter handling, (c) parameter expression handling. Please try to consolidate or comment why you want to leave it - if there's a good reason, that's fine too.
2) Commented code: Could you please also delete the unused commented code fragments (it's unnecessary to keep that since it can be restored from the history and only confuses people).
3) Error messages: There are a couple of error messages that are completely useless. An example is "incorrect lvalue ... strange" - even if we think a certain code path will never be taken, it will happen and we don't want these kinds of messages showing up in error logs.
4) Package qualification: Please also remove any unnecessary package specification of classes - the only acceptable reason would be that you want to use two classes from different packages in the same file. In such a case, please use the minimal package extension to differentiate them, not the full package name.
5) Unnecessary files: Please remove any unnecessary files like "package-info.java". If the only reason is a global comment, add it to the main entry class of that package. In this particular case, we could just remove it. Also, please don't put JIRA numbers into any comments.
6) Unnecessary class nesting: Could you please flatten SyntacticErrorListener ? Why would we need a class that has only another class (CustomErrorListener ) in it? 
7)  Unknown data type parsing: Further, the current version of getConstIdFromString seems a bit like to hack. Could you please think about a cleaner version, maybe based on valid characters (please also have a look at existing commons libs like StringUtils).
8) Code style: Finally, it would be good to fix the remaining code style issues as well. This includes (a) typos (e.g., constoubleIdExpressionHelper), (b) the unnecessary use of "compareTo()==0" ("equals" would do just fine), (c) conditional boolean assignments (e.g., val=false; if( A.equals(B) ) val=true; should become val = A.equals(B), and (d) please try to avoid "} else {" since it's unreadable. Thanks.

@mboehm7 For the methods I did not refactor out (control structures and below), additional work would need to be done in DmlSyntacticValidator & PydmlSyntacticValidator and the gains (if any) did not seem worth it. Case if point - exitExternalFunctionDefExpression; A for loop over a list of StrictParameterizedKeyValueStringContext (which a Parser specific type) would need to be done in each SyntacticValidator before any common code could be refactored out.

I could have overlooked this, but I could not find the case you've mentioned in 8(c).
wrt 8c: there is an example in CommonSyntacticValidator.getConstIdFromString, boolean case
That function has changed now as part of addressing the comments.
Submitted a Jenkins [build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/91/)
[Build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/91/) Passed
@lresende Also, do we need two LICENSE files, or can we reduce it to one?
@mboehm7 Could you please take a look?

thanks for the updates @nakul02. There are just some minor cleanups remaining. @deroneriksson could you please merge this in once Nakul did the cleanups?

1) History: Please, double check that the history of CustomErrorListener still exists. Currently it looks like SyntacticErrorListener w/ nested subclass CustomErrorListener has been deleted and re-created as CustomErrorListener. If the history is not present, please do separate commits for the rename and the code change, and squash commits.
2) Cleanup: Get rid of all unused imports (e.g., com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.ser.std.NumberSerializers.IntegerSerializer)
3) Code style: Finally, it would be good to condense unnecessary branches (e.g., exitMatrixDataTypeCheck, instead of "if(pre){}else{exception}" please do if(!pred){exception})

thanks @asurve this looks already much better - a couple of issues to cleanup

1) Potential side effects: You maintain the list of update-in-place variables in debug mode as a static variable in order to facilitate automated tests. However, since you always maintain that in debug mode, it might create problems in specific cases, where multiple parfor optimizations happen concurrently (e.g., parfor w/ fixed parameters w/ nested optimized parfor). Please, either use ThreadLocal state or a specific flag that is only enabled by your test.
2) Logging: Furthermore, you currently output a lot of detailed information. Since debug is used to get a high-level idea of parfor plans and applied rewrites, please move your detailed output wrt candidates and things alike to log level TRACE.
3) Flag in parfor optimizer: Please add a flag 
APPLY_REWRITE_UPDATE_INPLACE_INTERMEDIATE to OptimizerRuleBased (enabled by default). This will allow us to quickly disable this feature if issues show up after the initial commit.
4) Statistics: First, please only show the update-in-place stats if it was a parfor script (because parfor is the only place where we apply it right now). Have a look at (parforOptCount>0). Second, currently you redundantly use atomics and synchronized, please remove the unnecessary sychronized from the increment methods.
5) Code Style: First, please update the comment "guaranteed to be a last-level block (see hop change)" - it's wrong because you recompile the entire parfor program. Second, some minor stylistic issues: size() == 0 -> isEmpty; size() > 0 -> !isEmpty(); listUIPRes.removeAll(listUIPRes) -> listUIPRes.clear(); and if( (bInLoop) || (pb instanceof WhileProgramBlock ... ) becomes if( bInLoop || pb instanceof WhileProgramBlock ). Third, please make your methods private or protected (not package visible). Fourth, please rename getUIPConsumerList -> rGetUIPConsumerList
and validateUIPConsumerList -> rValidateUIPConsumerList to make clear these are recursive methods.
6) Tests: First, it would be nice if your UpdateInPlaceTest would include a class-level comment what the individual tests are (e.g., test for functions, test for interleaved statements, etc). Second, updateinplace12.dml does not need the if(1==1) cut because it already includes control flow. Third, please remove unused code.
Did we actually arrive at a consensus on this JIRA?

@mboehm7 
wrt 1, squashing the commits for the rename and code change loses the history for the file.
If the two commits are separate, the history is retained. 
What do you suggest?
then let's keep them separate for now and bring them together when merging.

WRT item 2 (the warning message), right now in the project, the warning message about the default config file appears even if a config file is explicitly specified (and found) via -config(=).

Maybe the logic/wording of the messages can be changed:
1) Maybe an INFO if a config file is found saying that the config file was found (at ...). It might be nice for the user to know that the config file has indeed been found.
2) Maybe a WARN but with more information if no config file is found, such as "No SystemML-config.xml found at ... (and ...). For optimal SystemML performance, it is highly recommended that you reference a SystemML-config.xml file."

@mboehm7 To preserve the history, I now have 3 commits.
1) Work to refactor
2) commit that uses "git mv" to rename SyntacticErrorListener.java to CustomErrorListener.java
3) commit that addresses other comments on this PR

Squashing commit 2 (even with the rename-threshold option) gets rid of the history for SyntacticErrorListener.java

Commit 2) does not compile.
A downside to this approach is that we will have a commit in the history that does not compile.

Submitted a Jenkins [build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/95/)

Jenkins [build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/95/) passed.
@deroneriksson, can you please take a look?

well, I still think it should be possible to merge these commits into one but cannot look into it right now. @lresende any thoughts?
@mboehm7 I'll take a look (WRT merging the 3 commits)

@mboehm7 Spent a couple hours trying to squash the 3 commits to 1 commit while retaining history for the CustomErrorListener (which was renamed), but without success. I would think that rename-threshold should help do this but I was unsuccessful.
LGTM, but why only for GLM?

thanks @asurve, we're almost there - please (1) use LOG.isTraceEnabled() in places where you only use LOG.trace(), (2) merge the update-in-place stats output with the existing parfor output, where update-in-place being the last two entries in this category.

@mboehm7 Ethan Xu asked about these warnings when he first ran GLM , so I wanted to be responsive and address his concerns in a prompt manner since he's providing us valuable feedback. I'll create another JIRA to validate and fix any similar issues in other algorithms.
thanks @deroneriksson that would be very useful

Welcome @sourav-mazumder ! Thank you for creating this example Zeppelin notebook.

Unfortunately, the contribution did not come over properly. The 2BCHR4T1Q directory same over as an empty file rather than a directory, so the notebook JSON file isn't present. I recently created a document about contributing to SystemML that may help, at http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/contributing-to-systemml.html#systemml-on-github .

Please let me know if you have any questions.

In the past, this is what we had to do, to avoid git removing history because the changes on a file was too disrupting for git to identify as rename. There should be no reason for not committing these as different commits, but maybe you want to "cleanup" the commit messages with the JIRA info, etc.
LGTM; thanks @asurve - there are a couple of potential improvements but those can be addressed in separate PRs.
Can an Admin verify this patch?
thanks @Wenpei; @niketanpansare could you please take a look.

Hi Wenpei, 

Thanks for your contribution. But, I believe your code does exactly the same thing as https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/LogisticRegression.java. This class is fully compatible with Scala API and won't require separate jar. May be I am missing something. Is there any particular reason why you think we should create wrappers in Scala instead ?

Thanks,

Niketan.

@Wenpei 
Fair point, Java API is little cumbersome for developers of the API as one needs to understand how Java developers can use certain Scala features. However, it does not affect usability with respect to the end user. The main advantage of having Java API is "easy integration with current dev setup".

Btw, I am OK with having a Scala API into incubator-systemml if following conditions are met:
1. "mvn verify" creates a jar with the Scala APIs in it and also runs the unit tests that verifies the Scala API. This will ensure that the future commits do not break the Scala API. 
2. Common dev setup (preferably eclipse or Scala IDE) for both the Scala API and the runtime. That is, scala files are compilation units inside the eclipse editor. This will encourage other committers to work contribute to the Scala API.

Thanks,

Niketan.

I'm in favor of replacing the existing Java APIs ([LogisticRegression](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/LogisticRegression.java), [MLContext](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/MLContext.java), etc.) with Scala versions in order to alleviate the types of issues raised here that are inherent with user-facing APIs.  We could simply place these Scala APIs in `src/main/scala` and keep the same package structure as before.

So, currently our `LogisticRegression` API is is part of the `org.apache.sysml.api.ml` package, and therefore the actual [LogisticRegression.java](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/LogisticRegression.java) file is located at `src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/LogisticRegression.java`.  We could instead place the Scala file at `src/main/scala/org/apache/sysml/api/ml/LogisticRegression.scala`, and use the same `org.apache.sysml.api.ml` package identifier.

To alleviate build issues, we can just integrate Scala compilation into Maven.  A quick search shows that the [scala-maven-plugin](https://github.com/davidb/scala-maven-plugin/) can do just this by simply adding a few lines to the [pom.xml](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/pom.xml), as shown in [1].  Eclipse integration appears to also be easy by simply adding a few more lines to the [pom.xml](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/pom.xml), as show at the bottom of [2].  Then, a simply `mvn package`, or Eclipse (or IntelliJ) build would work as usual.  No additional JARs would be necessary in the final packaged `SystemML.jar` file either.

This route would also be great in preparation for [SYSTEMML-451](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-451), which aims add DML as an embedded Scala DSL.
- [1]: [http://davidb.github.io/scala-maven-plugin/example_java.html](http://davidb.github.io/scala-maven-plugin/example_java.html)
- [2]: [http://davidb.github.io/scala-maven-plugin/faq.html](http://davidb.github.io/scala-maven-plugin/faq.html)

@niketanpansare Great!  The goal for replacing [MLContext](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/java/org/apache/sysml/api/MLContext.java) as well would relate to the issue of default parameters.  There are currently 18 variations of `registerInput(...)`, and 23 variations of `execute(...)`/`executeScript(...)` and it just keeps getting messier with each new parameter or parameter type.

Also, I can't speak for Eclipse, but IntelliJ works great for Spark (which is now a mixed Scala/Java project) as well as SystemML.
Can be previewed [here](http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/dml-language-reference.html).
LGTM.
LGTM.

Tried this out on Spark and it works great.  Having the ability to automatically infer a CSV format for a ".csv" file extension is smart, and avoids confusion for the new user.  This doesn't affect any existing options such as supplying a `format="csv"` argument to the `read(...)` statement, and instead will simply add a much-needed convenience.

Also, I ran this using our standalone distribution, and received a `java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.apache.commons.io.FilenameUtils` error.  No problems on Spark though.
LGTM.
@lresende ping.
Yeah, let's just commit this as multiple commits, each with the proper JIRA title.

@niketanpansare @dusenberrymw 
I work out a init pom.xml for scala support, which works for `mvn clean package` to produce a `SystemML.jar`.
But I face two issues here:
1. It's very large for `SystemML.jar` , about 30M in my compute.  Not very sure but my be reasonable.
2. I don't know how to change compile order to make compile java at first, which cause class not found issues in eclipse. 

I am not very good at maven config / pom, so is anyone can help to review this.

beside this, systemml has folder like "/systemml/src/test_suites/java", we may need change it to "/systemml/src/test/java", and add "systemml/src/test/scala" to follow plugin rule.

Regards.
Yu Wenpei.
@Wenpei Will look into this today.
Thanks @dusenberrymw, submitted Jenkins [build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/100/)

@Wenpei Thanks for updating the POM file.  
1. I think the issue with regards to size is due to the inclusion of the Scala library dependencies into to final JAR.  Since this specific log reg API will only ever be used from Spark, we can assume that those Scala libraries will be available at runtime, and thus we don't need to include them in the JAR.  Can you set the "scope" on all the Scala dependencies you added to "provided", indicating that they should not be included in the JAR?

@Wenpei Please do following things before making the switch:
1. Change all the scala dependency to provided. This should bring the jar down to 6M. @dusenberrymw mentioned this already :)
1. Please make sure the jar works on a cluster without Spark/Scala (as well as with Spark/Scala) on all the execution modes (i.e. standalone, hybrid, ....). I have done sanity test on our internal cluster which has both Spark/Scala (on the above 6M jar), but I would highly recommend using our performance test suite to ensure that there are no unintentional side-effects. Also please make sure you run the integration test suite  (i.e. mvn verify).
2. Please try the new setup on eclipse (and the IDE of your choice (IntelliJ)) on Mac/Windows and see if you are getting compilation errors. 
3. Please provide instructions to switch to new setup (for example: download certain version of Scala, certain version of IDE, etc ...) to other committers.
There was an issue with Jenkins on the last build.  Started [build 101](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/101/).

Well, I don't have a strong opinion on the wrapper code. The only hard requirement is that it has to work nicely with eclipse - no matter what.

1.  work on instruction those days and put it to dev folder. 
2. do some test to make sure `SystemML.jar` works fine.

@deroneriksson Should be better to add OPTIONAL column for input parameter and avoid to long for line 39.
Thanks @Wenpei, I really appreciate the effort :)

Great catch @dusenberrymw . I had assumed commons-io was already added to the libs for standalone since it is such a common library, but I was mistaken. I'll update the standalone assembly to include it. 

@mboehm7 I don't believe there was a consensus. My main concern with this issue is that I would prefer not to intimidate new users by requiring them to do things like `echo '{"rows": 306, "cols": 4, "format": "csv"}' > data/haberman.data.mtd` when they first try to use one of the main algorithms. The required metadata file for csv (if there was no format parameter) was one of the things I first felt frustrated by when I started using SystemML. If I created a csv file containing "1,2,3,4", I did not want to also have to create a JSON-formatted metadata file. Perhaps we can get feedback from some new users to find out if others feel the same way?

As a new user of SystemML I vote for the idea. When I first started to use SystemML the accidental errors in meta data was the most frustrating part. It took me awhile to search through documentations to find my mistakes only to find the error was a typo in mtd. 

To build a simple sample I had to write 3 mtds manually:
- For the original data file

``` bash
echo '{
    "data_type": "frame",
    "format": "csv",
    "sep": ",",
    "header": false,
    "na.strings": [ "NA", "null", "NULL", "NaN" ]
}' | hadoop fs -put - my.data.file.csv.mtd
```
- For the type file as an input argument of the transform() function:

``` bash
echo '1,2,2,1,1' | hadoop fs -put - file-type.csv
echo '{"rows": 1, "cols" : 5, "format":"csv"}' | hadoop fs -put - file-type.csv.mtd
```
- For splitting percentage file as input of 'sample.dml'

``` bash
printf "0.7\n0.3" | hadoop fs -put - split-perc.csv
echo '{"rows": 2, "cols": 1, "format": "csv"}' | hadoop fs -put - split-perc.csv.mtd
```
I think the first one is not avoidable though.

Tests run: 4799, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0

thanks @gweidner - couple of comments:

1) Tests: For testing purposes it would be good to use a larger eps value (e.g., 0.1 instead of 1e-17); otherwise we're always in danger that it is ignored given the test tolerance of 1e-6.
2) Rewrites: Currently, you apply this rewrite for both / and *. Since the runtime only supports /, please change it to / only when checking for VALID WDIVMM binary operations. 
3) Instruction Generation: Could you please use the same instruction layout for CP and Spark and only use "instruction patching" for MR where it is required? This applies to the lops WeightedDivMM and WeightedDivMMR.
4) Spark Quaternary Instruction: According to 3, you would need to change the instruction parsing. Also, please think about a solution where eps is not put into the operator but treated as input data.
5) LibMatrixMult: In matrixMultWDivMMDense, could the case "scalar and x==null" happen at all; if not, please simplify. In matrixMultWDivMMSparseDense, where do you actually pass in the scalar value? In all three methods, could you please unpack the scalar value once and reuse it over all iterations?

Once, this pr is in, could you please also have a look into step 2 of [SYSTEMML-510]? I'll take care of step 3.
Thank you Matthias for the feedback.  I've pushed commit for item 1 to use larger eps value and will push additional commits separately to incorporate the other comments.
Successful tests results for latest commit available at [build 174](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/174/).

Updated RewriteAlgebraicSimplificationDynamic.java for 2 new patterns to '/' only.  Verified 84 tests in WeightedDivMatrixMultTest all passed in local test environment.  Full automated test build in progress [build 175](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/175/).

Hi @Wenpei . Thank you for reviewing. I wrapped the input parameters on line 39 to a new line for readability. The OPTIONAL column is a nice idea, but the DEFAULT column includes this information, since if a default value is present, the input parameter is optional. If we receive more feedback that this is unclear, maybe we can add an OPTIONAL column to all scripts in the future.

All tests passed in [PR build 177](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/177/).
Previous PR build 175 reported single test failure in functions.recompile.ReblockRecompileTest.testReblockGroupedAggregate most likely due to randomly generated seed value in runReblockTest.

Pushed additional commit for comment (5) to update scalar handling in matrixMultWDivMMSparseDense, matrixMultWDivMMDense, matrixMultWDivMMGeneric of LibMatrixMult.

LGTM; however keep in mind, the only reason why this works (despite the fact that we don't support variable formats) is constant propagation. However, this is fine because most data generators do the same thing to simply usage.

These changes look good @gweidner - just some final cleanups: 
ad 3) Please use the same approach for WeightedDivMM as you did for WeightedDivMMR (both apply to the MR backend, where "R" just stands for "Reduce"-side w/ shuffle)
ad 5) It would be good to consistently use 'eps' instead of x[0].
6) Looking over (3) made me realize that this change currently always compiles a WeightedDivMMR for MR (even if both factors fit into the broadcast budget) and always a WeightedDivMM for Spark (even if the factors do not fit in). Could you please change QuaternaryOp for both MR and Spark. For Spark, please change the condition of isMapWsloss (currently it is ignoring forced op types and memory budgets; also please rename this variable to isMapWdivmm). For MR, add similar conditions as you already did for Spark. Thanks.

Thank you Matthias for all the pointers!
I've pushed updated WeightedDivMM (MR exec type with prepScalarInput) and LibMatrixMult (consistent eps referencing/unpacking in matrixMultWDivMMDense).
Item 6 is in progress and item 4 under investigation.
LGTM
I agree with @deroneriksson ... the fact that a parameter has default value means it is optional.
LGTM
Thanks, i agree

All tests passed in [PR build 181](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/181/) and on-demand [build 104](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/104/).

@deroneriksson The changes here looks good, but as we are also making some of these html/css files under doc folder available on the source distro, we need to include another LICENSE for the source distro that only include the licenses related to doc. When we have the LICENSE for source distro, we should update the source assembly to use those when producing the source distro. Other then that LGTM.

Is this the best way to provide java opts to standalone execution? It may misled users into thinking that they can pass  such java opts for driver/CP process in distributed execution as well -- something similar to `HADOOP_CLIENT_OPTS` in Hadoop.

Two options:
1. Either change the env var to make it explicit that it is applicable only for standalone execution
2. Instead of env var, have such property in the config file .. just like the way we had jvm properties for distributed execution. I prefer this but does not have a strong opinion.
